awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Developing a temporally adaptive decomposition framework for analyzing long-term echosounder time series
awd_abstract_narration:
Scientific echosounders are high-frequency active sonar systems used extensively to study life in the ocean, especially the least-characterized mid-trophic animals, such as zooplankton and fish. The recent surge in the deployment of autonomous echosounders has resulted in a deluge of echo data from a variety of ocean observing platforms, including vehicles and moorings. These data sets harbor great potential for advancing our understanding of marine ecosystems at spatial and temporal scales never before possible. However, the volume and complexity of the data make efficient and effective analysis a major challenge. This research is aimed at establishing a data-driven methodology to automatically extract features from echosounder data, thus unblocking this bottleneck between instrumentation capacity (to collect large data) and interpretation capability (to analyze large data). The developed method will expedite the currently labor-intensive data analysis process and help extract synoptic information from large echo data sets. Results of this research will be disseminated through open-source echo analysis software packages and online educational materials created as integrated components of this project. This research contributes directly to improving our ability to better understand the marine ecosystems, which are critical for global biodiversity and the economic well-being of a significant population of society.

This research will develop a method for automated discovery and tracking of low-dimensional spatio-temporal structures from high-dimensional echo data by adapting a state-of-the-art dynamic non-negative matrix factorization (NMF) formulation. NMF is an unsupervised machine learning technique that decomposes complex data into a linear combination of a smaller set of quantitative descriptors that are more tractable and interpretable than the original data. This technique has found great success in many basic research and applied fields, including computer vision, neuroscience, natural language processing, and recommender systems for internet retailers. In the context of echo analysis, these low-dimensional descriptors characterize the vertical movements and grouping activities of marine organisms in the water column imaged by the echosounder. However, traditional NMF does not account well for a changing set of phenomena in the data. Therefore, this project aims to develop a method that can provide a temporally adaptive decomposition in order to accommodate the complexity and high temporal variability of transient features in long-term echosounder data. The researchers will use data collected by the two cabled Endurance Array echosounders in NSF?s Ocean Observatories Initiative (OOI) as a test bed for methodology development. The stability, robustness, and interpretability of the developed method will be evaluated and compared with conventional echo analysis routines. This effort will lay the foundation for further machine learning and statistical studies of large echo datasets from the OOI and other ocean observing systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Echosounders are high-frequency (tens to hundreds of kHz) sonar systems that are widely used to study life in the ocean and monitor fishery resources. The overarching goal of this project was to develop new tools which can effectively glean biological information from long-term echosounder time series from moorings, such as those collected by those from the Ocean Observatories Initiative (OOI) network. Two sets of main outcomes were generated under this project: 1) a new data-driven methodology suitable for extracting information from echograms from long-term moorings, and 2) a new open-source Python software package that lays the groundwork for processing large volumes of echosounder data.

 

The data-driven methodology is based on matrix decomposition, a class of unsupervised learning techniques that are widely used in many scientific domains. In this project, we developed a two-stage approach that can automatically remove noisy outliers and discover distinct daily echogram patterns from the data. One of the daily echogram patterns we discovered corresponds with the diel vertical migration (DVM) behavior that happens ubiquitously in the global ocean in a diurnal cycle. During DVM, many marine animals migrate upward to feed near the surface at dusk and dive back down at dawn to avoid visual predators that can hunt effectively when the water is well illuminated. Another daily echogram pattern we discovered captured a temporally transient layer that changed depth and strength during the analyzed period, with the changes coinciding with significant local movements of water masses observed separately by an acoustic Doppler current profiler (ADCP). Our analyses showed that these automatically discovered daily echogram patterns make it much easier to track, visualize, and interpret variations in long-term echosounder data. 

 

In parallel, we developed an open-source Python software package ?Echopype? to streamline the data preprocessing and standardization steps required to apply the new methodology to large volumes of data collected by the OOI echosounders. Recognizing the fact that this data wrangling step is a common need and a key obstacle for many research projects, in addition to making the software package open and free to anyone, we have also actively engaged the ocean acoustics and fisheries acoustics communities in this development. Apart from individual scientists who use Echopype for their own research, the OOI Data Center has adopted Echopype to parse and serve data from both cabled and uncabled echosounders on the network; the NOAA National Centers for Environmental Information (NCEI) Water Column Sonar Data archive, who archives all echosounder data generated in NOAA missions, is also evaluating Echopype in order to upgrade their data ingestion and visualization pipeline to the cloud.

 

Together, the new methodology and software developed under this project pushed the boundary of the field of active acoustics by incorporating data science approaches in echosounder data analysis, which will benefit not only oceanographic research but also more broadly the management of marine resources that is critical for sustainability under the changing climate.
